The idea that both sides of any argument have an equally valid point is a fallacy, and drives me nuts. I understand CC wants to be neutral and let people think for themselves but in this case, CC was overly kind to the anti-NN side. The idea that traffic shaping/QoS is a "pro" for the anti-NN side is preposterous. ISPs can and do (and should) throttle traffic based on data/application TYPE. Live video and real-time applications (e.g. gaming) should be given priority over something like email. NN doesn't want to take that away. NN prevents ISPs from throttling traffic based on factors such as source (partners vs others), subscriber status (unsubscribed, subscribed, premium, etc), and content TYPE (such as political viewpoints that special interest groups dislike), which as you can understand is fertile ground for abuse. This is equivalent to the ridiculous scare tactic of shouting "Obama is coming to take ALL of yer guns away!!!"

The issue with the claim that competition would discourage bad behavior among ISPs is that they often operate as oligopolies and/or local monopolies. When you only have one or two choices of where to get your internet, it's very easy for a small handful of corporations to collude for their mutual benefit, working against the consumer's best interests. If you look at two of the most unpopular industries in America, cable companies and airlines, you can see the oligopoly model in effect. When Comcast and Time Warner only have to worry about competing with each other, it's not difficult to see why both can get away with treating their customers poorly.
You mention competition as a possible discouragement for bad behavior but do not bring up that there is often at best little to no alternatives to customers, especially at cable or fiber speeds.

That is the problem. Where I live, I have exactly two internet provider choices.  They both charge the same, but because of my exact location, one offers speeds 10x the other for the same price.  That slow one DOES offer equal speeds in other parts of town, though.  Parts of town that have three or more competitors...  So even though I SIGNIFICANTLY dislike the business practices, I have to "swallow my pride" and get the faster provider, because I work from home, and my work means I NEED the faster connection.  (My internet connection is ~125 Mbps download, ~25 Mbps upload. The other internet provider in theory offers 40 Mbps download, 5 Mbps upload to my neighborhood; but my house can only get 20 Mbps download, *1.5*Mbps upload at maximum. I used to have that provider, and had them replace equipment and lines multiple times to try to get the "offered" 40/5 speeds.  Even then, 5 Mbps would have made my job difficult.  At 1.5, it was impossible.  In other parts of town, they offer 1000 Mbps both up and down.  Not here.)  Edit: Out of curiosity, I decided to double check with the "slow" provider, just in case they had updated my neighborhood in the 2 years since I last checked with them.  Nope. In fact, now they only list my house at 12 Mbps download...  So it has gotten worse.
ISPs in the US are a massive and tragic failure of anti-trust laws.

This was my thought exactly.  You can't trust "market pressures and competition" to discourage bad behavior when there's no competition to begin with!  And as we've seen with things like Comcast's notoriously awful customer servicre, these massive corporations don't care an ounce for their customer's experience or their reputation, because they're the only option to begin with.

Yeah, the ISP business is a pretty clear-cut example of a natural monopoly - once you've run a cable along a street, it's a lot cheaper for you to run branches off into individual properties than it is for your competitor to run a new cable along the same street. If you're the only ISP serving a particular community, then the barriers are even steeper since the competition now needs to run the cable from the next town (or further).  Natural monopolies have a built-in resistance to market forces because a new competitor has to absorb significant costs before they can start rivaling the established company's marginal costs.
Exactly

It's a monopoly because the government made it that way. So net neutrality would only fix a problem that was created by the government in the first place. The better approach would be to remove the ability for government to control which ISPs control which areas.
@ShiningDialga  There's no competition because of the government, not because of any natural forces.
@rmsgrey  It's not a natural monopoly if the government had a significant hand in forming it

@thinkngskeptic  A "natural monopoly" just means that a high cost-to-entry makes it impractical for people to compete. If I want to set up a new ISP in some small town a hundred miles away from the nearest place I already have high bandwidth access to the internet, then I need to set up 100 miles of cable to get data to and from the town. That's a significant upfront investment and the money to do that has to come from somewhere.   If I'm the first to run a wire into town, then that gives me a temporary monopoly, and I can set my prices high enough to cover that setup cost and the running costs and then lower prices after a couple of years once I've got back my initial investment and only need to cover ongoing maintenance. Once that happens, if Bob comes along and decides that he wants to set up a second ISP in town, either he needs to make a deal with me to use my cable, or he needs to spend the money to run a second hundred mile cable. If he pays me for the use of my cable, I can set the price high enough that he can't afford to compete with my prices; if he runs his own cable, then he can't afford to compete with my prices until after he's paid off the cost of that cable.   So, without any government intervention, in either direction, internet provision is a natural monopoly. It's just massively more efficient for there to just be one cable into town, so one set of building costs, and one set of ongoing maintenance costs, rather than having two or more companies maintaining separate cables.   Government intervention can make matters worse - for example, by subsidising the first cable into town - but it's not needed in order for there to be a strong tendency for there to only be a single ISP in a given region.

​ @rmsgrey  I understand your argument, you believe there would still be many monopolies without governemnt intervention because of the high cost of entry/expansion. It's a valid argument, but let's check whether the premises are true.   As a general rule, the less competition, the higher the prices and the lower the quality. So, you have your work cut out for you in supporting the political oppression of entrepreneurs. I'm not calling you a bad person, I think most people haven't internalized that regulations are enforced at the point of a gun and threatening innocent people doesn't improve society. That's one rebuttal that's both on moral and economic principle grounds.   But to address your main point that ISPs would be monopolies without government and the reason it would be even worse is because resources would be wasted by people trying and failing to compete, I have a few rebuttals.   1) You seem to think you're smarter than the average entrepreneur (and maybe you are) because you believe that entrepreneurs would continue to invest money into a business that's destined to fail. But it's extremely unlikely that that would happen if, like you said, one cannot compete with an established ISP. Investors would simply not give entrepreneurs the capital to try to compete if it's so clear they can't.   2) It's not true that businesses can only offer reasonable prices once they're making a profit. Plenty of successful companies start off offering competitive prices while their books are still in the red. Some companies operate at a loss for years before making a profit.   3) Your example of a small town 100 miles away is designed to constrain the debate too much in your favor. It's an exception to the rule.   4) Satellite internet, while slower and more expensive than average, would still be a check on the prices of the local ISP.   5) Monopolies are not better for the consumer than a number of competing companies just because they only require one set of buildings and infrastructure. You're ignoring the fact that if other companies are prevented from competing with the monopoly, it can raise prices and run the company poorly all it wants because nobody else is offering an alternative. If you're in a running race and nobody else is allowed to beat you, you can just walk.

@thinkngskeptic  I'm not sure quite what point you're trying to argue here.   Yes, government regulation can (and has) made things worse when it comes to ISP diversity in the US. That's independent of whether or not internet provision is a natural monopoly.   Actually, it would be more precise to say that telecommunications infrastructure is a natural monopoly - if you have the wires owned and maintained by a neutral third party, then individual companies can compete on a level playing field and fair competition is possible.
@rmsgrey  when you say "is a natural monopoly," do you mean currently, or in theory it would be without the intervention, or both?

@thinkngskeptic  Both. There's a high barrier to entry anyway, and, in some nations/states, the local laws and regulations provide an additional barrier (without going so far as to formally grant a monopoly)
@rmsgrey  Ans the size of the city doesn't affect this, in your view?

@thinkngskeptic  Size of city and proximity to internet hubs make a big difference. There are still going to be natural monopolies on a much smaller scale - if neighbours both sides already have Bob-fibre connections, Bob will be able to hook you up much more easily than Jim who'll need to run a new cable from two blocks over - but that's natural monopolies on the scale of individual blocks or individual apartment buildings, rather than across an entire city. And if you have municipal fibre, that both Bob and Jim can tie your connection into, then the barrier to entry pretty much goes away (though large buildings may still tend to be monopolies)
@rmsgrey  You think two blocks makes such a big difference to an ISP that they wouldn't attempt to expand there?
If I had a choice in internet provider, do you think I would be paying $70/month for 10 Mbps? The US internet industry is uncompetitive in many places.

I am disappointed that you repeat the strawman about QoS and net neutrality being opposed to each other. Net neutrality does not demand that all KINDS of services be prioritized the same, just that all ENDPOINTS be prioritized the same. VOIP packets can get prioritized over email packets and the net is still neutral, so long as ANYONE's VOIP packets are treated the same as anyone else's VOIP packets, etc. It's only when Comcast prioritizes NBC streaming video over Netflix streaming video that it becomes non-neutral; it's fine if all video takes priority over all email, nobody objects to that.

The S is for Secure. There's an additional layer of encryption in it.
hypertext transfer protocol secure
the S is for "secured" meaning there is extra security levels in place to protect data. For example your credit card information for a purchase should be done on an https site.

The S is for "Secure", because your web browser will encrypt the HTTP requests it sends (and decrypt the ones it receives from the server) using SSL. It also uses a different port for traffic (port 443 as opposed to port 80) to differentiate the traffic.

varana312  The s doesn't signal encryption, it signals that you communicate with a verified server. SSL certificates are handed out by a semi centralized system that verifies that you communicate with the original owner of a URL. So, you can be sure that nobody is in-between you and your original target (eg your bank).

asshole9191 "SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) is a standard security technology for *establishing an encrypted link between a server and a client*—typically a web server (website) and a browser; or a mail server and a mail client (e.g., Outlook). It allows sensitive information such as credit card numbers, social security numbers, and login credentials to be transmitted securely. To establish this secure connection, the browser and the server need an SSL Certificate." https://www.digicert.com/ssl-cryptography.htm
asshole9191 Nope, HTTPS run those SSL/TLS protocol, which is encrypted from get go.

What it https means is that your browser will, before requesting any page, request the public key for that site from a Certificate Authority, then encode the request using that public key so that in theory only the target site can understand your request (assuming they kept their private key private and used a sufficiently complex key). In turn, the site's reply to your browser is encrypted using their private key, so you can't understand the reply without the site's public key (plus some magic with your browser inventing a key pair for your request, because we don't everyone who can request their public key able to read all their outgoing traffic :) ). So I guess you could say that the Certificate Authority kinda verified the target server, but it's still hackable:  Say I want to get your password to Some Popular Site, 1) I could register a "close by" domain name and get a certificate for that domain name, and your browser will happily make an encrypted request to my domain that only I can read. This preys on "users rarely look carefully at urls" - so they don't notice that the link was to "SomePopuIarSite.com" (capital I instead of lowercase l) 2) Assuming I have greater means at my disposal (like if I have control of a router between you and the backbone), you're still vulnerable to a man-in-the-middle attack where I convince your browser to come to my site instead of somepopularsite.com . I just have to go the extra step to also spoof the certificate authority's site and deliver my public key to your browser, too (there's protection against this kind of hack in that your request for certificate is encrypted, too, but eventually you must have to get a public key for someone somewhere in a non-encrypted manner to start it all off and let you start reading encrypted things that give you keys to get the keys to get the keys to get my site's keys)  (I'm not a security or hacking expert, and there are probably errors in there - they are hopefully the result of lack of knowledge rather than stupidity - please be gentle when correcting me)

Garrett, that's not really what happened though, CC was overly kind to the anti-NN side. The idea that QoS is a "pro" for the anti-NN side is preposterous. ISPs can and do (and should) throttle traffic based on data/application TYPE. Live video and real-time applications (e.g. gaming) should be given priority over something like email. NN seeks to prevent ISPs from throttling traffic based on factors such as source, subscriber, and content TYPE, which as you can understand is fertile ground for abuse. I'm very happy they addressed it neutrally, even though I am pretty sure they are in favor of it. Crash Course is one of the few sources I can count on to give more or less unbiased information, which is absolutely essential especially for people who are learning about something for the first time.   For example, if Crash Course introduced net neutrality and said that it was bad, many people would end up believing that it is unambiguously bad. This could cause net neutrality laws to be removed and end up making the internet terrible and monopolistic.  By the same logic, if Crash Course, supported net neutrality, it could influence people to hang onto it and we might never experience the internet gloriously free of a stifling law.  The fact that we are still having this debate means that we don't know for sure if net neutrality is good or bad, and as such I have great respect for Crash Course for providing the unbiased platform and encouragement for people to learn about it and make their own decisions.

Actually that's exactly what happens. IPv6 has flow-label and traffic-class headers for this exact purpose. Classed networks is an important area of research.

All of this is why assigning a government organization to maintain net neutrality is probably better than writing specific laws to deal with it. Organizations with semi-independent agents are better at identifying people trying to exploit loopholes than laws ever could be, and it's quicker to change policy than write and approve new laws.

@*TheOlian04*  Exactly. So, where does that leave us? ISPs prioritising services according to where they came from and where they're going. Eg: Comcast prioritising NBC streaming video over Netflix, i.e: no net-neutrality.

Stephen Bly I looked into it, and you're absolutely right. In the context of net neutrality though, I want to add that, since those headers and labels are written by the source of the traffic, not by the isp, they are an opt-in prioritization. For instance, Skype may want their video content to go faster than their messages, so as a downstream optimization they let any intermediate routers know that the video content is higher priority, without needing to say "this is video content" or asking the routers to peek at the information. That doesn't necessarily mean that the routers, including the isp, respect those wishes. It is just a "contract", and I admittedly don't know how enforceable it is. It's a good point to make though, the problem that net neutrality addresses isn't that all internet traffic must be treated in the same way, but that this decision should not be made by the isp, who is essentially a middle-man profiting from their role in the transaction (albeit a necessary one with the current internet infrastructure).

That prioritizes certain endpoints, Comcast could say that the only video streaming sites they recognize are the ones they host.  Even if they expand this to include most of the popular video sites, there will still be traffic to smaller video sites that will get unfairly throttled, preventing new competition in the video hosting market.    The only way to ensure that all endpoints are treated equally is to give all packets the same priority.  Encrypted packets will throw a wrench in any plan to prioritize based upon information gleaned from packet contents and with more sites switching to https (the lock in the upper left of most browsers), there is more encrypted traffic than ever.  I bet most of the people watching this video did it over an encrypted connection.

You guys know that endpoint-neutral QoS is already a thing that exists, right? It's the thing that has always existed until the ISPs decided they wanted to be non-neutral with regard to endpoints. There is absolutely no question about technical possibility: it is happening right now. The only question is whether net neutrality proponents oppose it. They don't; everyone on both sides of the debate is OK with QoS. It is not being fair and balanced to say that net neutrality opponents oppose it for the sake of QoS, implying that proponents are against QoS. That is just misleadingly misrepresenting one side of the argument, framing them as against something that nobody is against, that already exists and has always existed.

Exactly, CSPs can and do prioritize certain TYPES of data packets, which makes sense. Live-video and gaming should happen in near-real time, compared to simple email and text-based traffic. But yes, it should only be throttled by TYPE of data/application--not by source, content, or by subscriber, since that would be dangerous territory for abuse and exploitation.

Basically I think she is starting with a bad definition, or one that needs to be updated at least. Technically, I don't think she said QoS but that's what it sounded like she was describing as an anti-NN argument. More of this "both sides have an equally valid point nonsense."

Yeah she didn't use the term QoS (which, for the sake of others here, stands for "Quality of Service" and refers to prioritizing different types of time-sensitive packets to ensure adequate... quality of service... for those applications). But it's clear that that's what she was talking about.  And FWIW I am generally in favor of presenting both sides of an argument even when I solidly prefer one side of it, but I draw the line when one side's "argument" is just claiming that the other side argues for something that they don't. Go ahead and present the reasons, if they have any, why anti-NN people are against it, just don't repeat their lies about what pro-NN people are for.
You know, she did actually address this, at about 10:40, with the specific example of email vs a VOIP call.

Email might be a bad example anyway. If Netflix were prioritised over my game packets, I would complain, because game packets are supposed to be for a real-time game, but Netflix packets can come in seconds late with no drawback as long as you're buffering the data.

I mean, are you a shill? Working for Comcast? AT&T? WB? A QoS service that runs on ISP networks and backbones absolutely violates net neutrality because differentiating kinds of services is as severe a violation of the core concept of neutrality as endpoints. If you pay your ISP for a certain speed of connection, and they then prioritize or deprioritize certain kinds of traffic unless you pay for their QoS "Mega Streaming Bundle," then that's just as bad. You're paying for the speed of your connection and then also a fee for how you use that speed?  That you paid for already? No endpoint differentiation required; all prioritization of traffic on any criteria violates net neutrality. That is in fact how they are most likely to start dragging us all into the worst case scenario. Besides, as many above me have pointed out, implementations vary far to much to identify traffic reliably by anything BUT the endpoint. What's behind your great love of QoS anyway? Pay for a faster connection. Unless you share access across a LAN, or live in a rural area with limited bandwidth, QoS at the WAN level isn't going to impact your service because that's not where the bottleneck is. If QoS is going to help you then you need it on your router locally anyway or else it's not going to make any difference. Also, it may seem obvious to you that video should take priority over email, but not all users are going to agree with you. Checking email requires almost no bandwidth by today's standards; if your streaming HD video has even a few seconds worth of video buffered any email download on the same connection is going register as barely a blip. Meanwhile, someone using email for a practical purpose may not wish to have their time sensitive, important, email check delayed because you happen to be watching Game Thrones on the same pipe. This is why net neutrality is important in the first place.

I don't know how you could think I'M a shill. I'm upset she's repeating an argument used by anti-NN advocates to misrepresent the pro-NN position. Anti-NN people say "but but but if net neutrality happens then torrents will make VOIP unusable", which is a straw man because you can still prioritize VOIP in general over torrents in general while remaining neutral in the important way (endpoints) that keeps ISPs from favoring their own content over competitors.  I don't especially care about QoS myself, I just know that anti-NN people use the threatened lack of QoS as an argument against NN, and that's fallacious. You can have endpoint neutrality (which is the important kind) and QoS at the same time. Or endpoint neutrality and QoS, I don't particularly care either way myself whether or not there's QoS, just that QoS isn't used as an excuse to circumvent endpoint neutrality.

and Keith, that is exactly the part I'm talking about. She is presenting an email vs VOIP scenario as an argument against net neutrality, when you can have a neutral network and still prioritize VOIP over email, so that argument misrepresents what NN proponents want: no discrimination between endpoints.

Pfhorrest: go back and relisten, and maybe do it a few time from about 10:40. She's not presenting email vs VOIP as an argument for or against NN in that last bit, just that certain kinds of traffic make sense to prioritise over others because they're not as time/latency/bandwidth sensitive, and that this kind of traffic shaping doesn't figure into NN. In fact, she says that specifically to narrow the argument down to what NN advocates want, which, as you stated, is no descrimination between endpoints.

+Pfhorrest  The distinction between global and local (e.g endpoint-only) neutrality was not made in the video, likely due to how broad the topic is. Instead, Carrie Anne presents only those arguments for and against global neutrality. Of course, ideally, endpoint-traffic is transmitted without discrimination, whilst still prioritising transmission speeds for time-sensitive data over the rest of the network, but as pointed out by others here, the feasibility of implementing such behaviour successfully is debatable.

Keith, maybe listen from a little bit earlier. That sentence she's in the middle of at 10:40 begins with "on the other hand", and follows an argument for net neutrality, which certain makes it sound like "some people want NN for these reasons, but then there are these others reasons not to have it". But those other reasons are not something NN excludes. You could have an endpoint-neutral network (what NN means, and what she's been discussing prior to that point), and still prioritize by type of traffic, so needing to prioritize by type of traffic is not a reason not to have an endpoint-neutral network. You can have both.  And Jivan: we DO currently have both, so the technical concerns are irrelevant, because they've long since already been addressed, since we're doing that right now, and have been doing that basically forever. Prioritizing by type but not endpoint is how the internet has been handled for ages, and how we (pro-NN) want it to stay. I don't know why you think "endpoint" means "local", but I think you're confused on the terminology. "Endpoint-neutral" means neutral with respect to WHO sent the packets, in contrast to WHAT the packets contain. We have always prioritized by "what", and what Carrie Anne is saying at 10:40 are the reasons why we need to. What's being debated is whether the ISPs can prioritize by "who". They never did before, and now that they're trying to start, we (pro-NN) want to ensure that they can't, and things stay how they have always been, instead of getting worse.  Only the anti-NN people want you to confuse the "what" issue with the "who" issue. "What" was never an issue. Only "who" is in question.

+Pfhorrest  Thanks for clearing up the terminology thing. I wasn't saying "endpoint" = "local", but that endpoint-NN is a form of local-NN, where local-NN is NN local to some point in the routing process, but I realise now that that doesn't make sense at all, since we're only concerned with the transmission speed between the source and the recipient, and not any intermediate nodes.  Gotta say, I now completely agree with you that this is feasible, if not already happening. (If we've already been prioritising data based on type in the past, could you give/refer to some examples of how this has been implemented? I'd be very interested to see the details, since I don't know of any metadata standard to identify the type of data sent over the Internet.)

Therein lies the issue though: a loss of net neutrality gives ISP owners huge control over what information is available to huge swaths of people.  You could end up with a company with strong political interests throttling the data of news sites or information they disagreed with, like certain political sites or scientific research.  No small group should have that much control over the information we have access to.

+Jivan Pal  Sorry but I don't actually know all the technical nitty gritty, just that it's happening already so must have been solved. Somehow or another ISPs are able to tell what kind of service what packets go with, and prioritize them based on that. I would guess that it's some combination of many things, like port number and some degree of packet inspection (looking for identifying headers).  One thing people have raised in concern in this thread is that ISPs can't inspect encrypted packets, but I'm pretty sure that the headers of encrypted packets are still readable, so the ISP can tell that it's e.g. HTTPS vs SSH vs VPN, even if it can't see what's being sent over those protocols. Of course you could route all your traffic through a VPN and then the ISP couldn't tell what's what to prioritize it, but in that case you probably want that result.

Pfhorrest Thank you for this clarification. As someone who works for an ISP I can confirm that QoS (based on WHAT is inside the packet) is actively being done and has been done for a very long time. It doesn't have anything to do with the current debate on Net Neutrality which is a question on how we treat different providers of the same type of traffic (the WHO question).
Jochem Kuijpers  asshole9191  good lord the two of you are stupid... thinking QoS can't be done.

@asshole9191 thats an awful analogy that shows a complete lack of understanding of the topic.  Its more like a warehouse putting more people on the heavy lifting jobs and less people on the lighter jobs but all heavy jobs are treated equally. Just because the warehouse may not like the person who sent them the delivery doesnt mean they can chose to not send any men to do the job and prioritise the packages from the companies they like.

The warehouse is still neutral if it prioritises the heavier jobs but it ISNT neutral if it starts prioritising the jobs based on what company gave them the package. That is the philosophy behind net neutrality

Another oddity I spotted was the sample page address, ending "/courses" without any specification of filetype. That suggests it's really the name of a folder, not an actual page.

+PastPresented Yeah, but that's common practice for hyperlinks to lead to folders with an index file. I wouldn't say it's an oddity, but yeah could be slightly misleading if someone knows nothing about the subject.

+PastPresented +snowdudelester or it could be a site that says "since we don't allow folder indexing, anyway, we may as well alias 'no file type' to '.html'" - especially common in sites that have a single gateway program and have something like this at the very bottom of their rewrite list (in apache): RewriteRule /(.*)  /content.php?page=$1
Yes it could, but as an example of how html (by itself, and, by implication of the preceding couple of sentences in the narration, as originally conceived) works, that's not helpful.
The point is that https://thecrashcourse.com/courses is the actual url of their example page - https://thecrashcourse.com/courses.html gives a (custom) 404 error. So I was just speculating as to why.

But there are multiple possible reasons why ! Still, I suppose it does hint that any file in correct html format should be interpreted as an html page, even though such files can have a wide variety of nominal filetypes. Maybe a later episode will go into the topic.
In the days they were talking about, unquoted attribute values were pretty common.

with simply routing trick you can direct that directory-likely-name url into actual page. using filetype like .html/.php/.asp/.jsp/etc is so ugly i think. or you can simply create directory named /courses and put index.html inside it, that index will be loaded when you call the directory.

Probably due to Caching; not only does your browser often save resources in a cache but high trafficked web servers use it in database query results, so when a new video comes up with a lot of subscribers two different queries may have been saved from two different time or the page is constructed from parts on two different machines and the data had not been synced to the load balancing server yet.
